titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Jackson Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by John Dojka

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:27

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, memoranda, and miscellaneous items of William Jackson, a major in the American Revolution and later an active political figure. Most of the items in the papers are letters received by Jackson between 1782 and 1828. Also included are memoranda relating to payments for surviving officers of the Continental Army and an account of the surrender of Lord Cornwallis. Among the correspondents are John Quincy Adams, Alexander Garden, Joseph Hopkinson, Ebenezer Huntington, Benjamin Lincoln, Charles Pinckney, John Sergeant and George Washington.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The entire collection is available on microfilm. Patrons must use FILM HM 210 instead of the originals.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William Jackson Papers. Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Henry Kirschenbaum to Beinecke Rare Book Library; transferred to Manuscripts and Archives, 1976.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Entire collectionis also available on microfilm (407 frames on 1 reel, 35 mm.) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library, at cost. Order no. HM210.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in three series: I. Incoming Correspondence. II. Manuscripts in the Hand of William Jackson. III. Miscellaneous and Printed Items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William Jackson Papers consist of approximately 120 items, the majority of which are letters received by Jackson during the years 1782 to 1828. Jackson corresponded with a large number of eminent men, among them George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, John Quincy Adams, William Henry Harrison, Henry Knox, and Charles Pinckney. However, most of the correspondence is routine in nature, e.g., cover letters, acknowledgements, and thank-you notes. Many of the letters, especially those written in 1818 and 1819, relate to efforts by Jackson and the Society of the Cincinnati to obtain the promised half pay of the surviving officers of the Continental Army. The bulk of this correspondence consists of letters acknowledging the receipt of memorials on behalf of the surviving officers and notes from sympathetic congressmen deploring the failure of Congress to act speedily on the matter.

The only material in the papers relating to Jackson's role as secretary to the Constitutional Convention is a letter from John Quincy Adams dated October 16, 1818, in which Adams asked Jackson if he had any material relating to the Constitutional Convention in his possession. Jackson responded that when he left Philadelphia in 1787 he turned over any relevant materials to Washington.

Other material of note includes several letters from the First Marquess of Landsdown (William Petty) commenting on Anglo-American relations and expressing his admiration of George Washington, a manuscript in Jackson's hand of a memorial to Congress on behalf of the surviving officers of the Continental Army, and an account, also in Jackson's hand, of Col. John Lauren's version of the surrender of Cornwallis at Yorktown.
The William Jackson Papers were given to Yale University Library by Henry Kirschenbaum, Purchase, New York, 1976 June 3.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: William Jackson was born in Cumberland, England, on March 9, 1759. Orphaned in early youth, Jackson was brought to South Carolina where he was raised under the guardianship of Owen Roberts. During the Revolutionary War Jackson served in the First South Carolina Regiment and later as an aide to Major-General Benjamin Lincoln. He subsequently served as Assistant Secretary of War under Lincoln (1782-1783). In 1787 he was appointed secretary of the Constitutional Convention and in the following year was admitted to the Pennsylvania Bar. From 1789 to 1791 Jackson served as personal secretary to President Washington and in 1796 was appointed Surveyor of Customs at Philadelphia. After losing his customs post in 1801 Jackson founded and edited the Philadelphia Political and Commercial Register (1801-1817).

Among his other notable activities Jackson was secretary of the Society of the Cincinnati from 1800 to 1828 and in this capacity was appointed by the surviving officers of the Continental Army to obtain for them an equitable adjustment of their promised half pay.
Jackson died in Philadelphia on December 18, 1828. For further information on his career see the Dictionary of American Biography .

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Incoming correspondence is arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent. Letters of a particular correspondent are organized chronologically.

odd.head: General
odd.p: With copies of two letters from Jackson to Adams: 19 and 21 October 1818
